purpose_overview.goal: Achieve fat loss and body recomposition by restricting the daily eating window while maintaining caloric control.
purpose_overview.approach: Time-restricted feeding (TRF) with fasting windows of 16, 18, or 20 hours, and feeding windows of 8, 6, or 4 hours respectively. Total daily calories and macronutrients remain the key driver of fat loss.
purpose_overview.best_for: Intermediate–advanced dieters, people who prefer fewer/larger meals, those with busy lifestyles, or those who struggle with grazing/snacking.
purpose_overview.why_it_works: Fasting helps naturally reduce calorie intake, may improve insulin sensitivity, appetite control, and metabolic flexibility (Tinsley & La Bounty, JISSN, 2015).

caloric_strategy.maintenance_calculation: Estimate TDEE using Mifflin-St Jeor or Cunningham equation.
caloric_strategy.target_weight_loss: 0.5–1.0% body weight per week (e.g., 0.4–0.8 kg for an 80 kg person).
caloric_strategy.adjustment_tip: If fat loss plateaus >2 weeks, reduce intake by 150–250 kcal/day or increase NEAT/cardio.

rationale.protein: Preserves lean muscle mass during calorie restriction. Higher protein helps offset fewer meal opportunities (Morton et al., 2018).
rationale.carbohydrates: Fuels training, supports recovery, preserves performance.
rationale.fats: Supports hormones, satiety, and absorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
rationale.fiber: Improves satiety, digestion, and gut health.

meal_timing_distribution.protein_distribution: 0.4–0.55 g/kg per meal × 2–4 meals (Schoenfeld & Aragon, JISSN, 2018).

training_integration.fasted_training: Consider EAAs/BCAAs (~10 g) or whey hydrolysate pre/intra to reduce muscle breakdown.
training_integration.pre_workout: Balanced meal 2–3 hr before, protein + complex carbs (if inside feeding window).
training_integration.post_workout: 20–40 g protein + 0.8–1.2 g/kg carbs within 2 hr (first meal if fasted).

meal_timing_distribution.hydration: 35–45 ml/kg/day water. Black coffee, tea, and zero-calorie drinks allowed during fasting. Electrolytes recommended during long fasts, hot climates, or heavy sweat sessions.

supplements_optional: Creatine Monohydrate (3–5 g/day) – Preserves strength and lean mass.
Whey/Plant Protein – Helps meet protein targets within limited meals.
Vitamin D & Omega-3 – Common deficiencies, aid health & recovery.
Caffeine (3–6 mg/kg pre-workout) – Boosts performance, especially in fasted training.
Electrolytes – Beneficial in fasted training or high sweat conditions.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – If <0.5% body weight loss for 2+ weeks, reduce calories or increase activity.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_progress: Weekly – If performance drops, increase carbs around training or slightly extend feeding window.
monitoring_adjustments.body_composition: Every 4–6 weeks – Use progress photos, BIA, or skinfolds.

advantages: May improve insulin sensitivity & metabolic health markers.
Useful for appetite control and snacking reduction.
limitations: Can be hard to hit calorie/protein targets in short windows (especially 20/4).
Not optimal for athletes needing frequent carb fueling.
Training performance may suffer if fasted.
scientific_references: Tinsley GM & La Bounty PM (2015). Effects of intermittent fasting on body composition and clinical health markers. J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 12:47.
Morton RW et al. (2018). Protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength. Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376–384.
Schoenfeld BJ & Aragon AA (2018). How much protein can the body use in a single meal for muscle-building? J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 15:10.
Kerksick CM et al. (2017). ISSN position stand: nutrient timing. J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 14:33.
American College of Sports Medicine (2022). Nutrition and Athletic Performance Position Stand.
